question.name: 16.5.3.1 Differentiation of Maclaurin series
question.questiontext:
Differentiation of Maclaurin series


We have already noted that, by the binomial series, \[ \dfrac{1}{1-x}=1+x+x^2+x^3+\cdots\qquad |x|<1.\] Thus, with \(x\) replaced by \(-x\) \[ \dfrac{1}{1+x}=1-x+x^2-x^3+\cdots \qquad |x|<1.\] We have previously obtained the Maclaurin expansion of \(\ln(1+x)\): \[ \ln (1+x)=x-\dfrac{x^2}{2}+\dfrac{x^3}{3}-\dfrac{x^4}{4}+\cdots \qquad -1<x\le 1.\] Now, we differentiate both sides with respect to \(x\):

\[ \dfrac{1}{1+x}=1-x+x^2-x^3+\cdots\] This result matches that found from the binomial series and demonstrates that the Maclaurin expansion of a function \(f(x)\) may be differentiated term by term to give a series which will be the Maclaurin expansion of \(\dfrac {\mathrm{d}f}{\mathrm{d}x}.\)

The derived series will have the same radius of convergence as the original series.
